I just messed up a forecast on another question because I siloed information.  I didn't link my high forecasts for a pre-New Year's surge in COVID with my forecast for TSA passengers.  If I was so confident that there would be a COVID surge, why didn't it occur to me that there'd be pilots, ground & cabin crews and passengers who would not be flying because they were sick!   I do not want to make the same mistake here.  Airline flights & passengers are way down because the Omicron COVID variant is beginning to surge.  I anticipate that air traffic will be quite low for about a month, as well will all kinds of other economic activity. . . so, what impact will that have on the price of WTI?

I've seen the volatility and movement of oil prices over many decades, sat in meetings and listened to the rationale for forecasts.  Ironically, now what may limit prices is demand.  However, as everyone knows the volatility is on the supply side, with the Permian producers and Opec+ + Russia always the unknown.  Brent has been running higher but given shale drillers new discipline, will this continue?  Last, $75 seems to be a hinge point; the ranges shown don't work well for my view.
With markets falling due to omicrom a rally before the end of the year to above 75 seems a close to zero possibility now.

Looks like prices have stabilized for a little bit but there's still a fair bit of volatility and a month left, so we could get a surprise, but the pressure seems off temporarily, likely at least long enough for the question to resolve. "The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-member allies such as Russia expect a surplus of 2 million barrels per day in January 2022, 3.4 million in February, and 3.8 million in March, according to a document viewed by Reuters on Wednesday." https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/commodities/oil-price-outlook-2022-opec-oversupply-forecast-crude-omicron-russia-2021-12
HT to @Anneinak for her analysis and link to NYT article.

https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/12/02/business/news-business-stock-market?campaign_id=51&emc=edit_mbe_20211203&instance_id=46869&nl=morning-briefing%3A-europe-edition&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=75971&te=1&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1#opec-plus-meeting-oil When officials from OPEC, Russia and other oil-producing countries met by video conference on Thursday . . .  The biggest concerns were whether the emergence of a new variant of the coronavirus might torpedo the budding global economic recovery, and the restiveness of the United States and key Asian customers, including China, over high oil prices. In the end,  the group known as OPEC Plus decided to take the easy route and stick with a previously agreed-to program of gradually adding oil to the market. It decided to raise production by 400,000 barrels a day in January, just as it has in recent months. But to show worried oil markets that they are ready to change that plan if needed, the producers said in a news release that their meeting would “remain in session” so the producers could monitor the market and “make immediate adjustments if required.” That  statement, analysts said, was intended to warn traders that OPEC Plus was ready to reconsider its production levels, including possibly cutting supplies, anytime the market appeared threatened — even before the next meeting scheduled for Jan. 4. “It puts a floor under prices, saying you don’t know what they are going to do,” said Bhushan Bahree, an executive director at IHS Markit, a research firm. “It matches uncertainty with uncertainty.” That message seemed to be sinking in, at least on Thursday. Prices dipped sharply as it emerged that OPEC Plus would raise production. But they recovered quickly, and later in the day futures were trading 1.7 percent higher, at about $70.10 a barrel for Brent crude, the international benchmark. The producers’ decision to keep adding oil to the market for now was also “a victory for the Biden administration,” wrote Helima Croft, head of global commodities at RBC Capital Markets. President Biden’s aides had pressured Persian Gulf producers to continue increasing production in the hope of reducing gasoline prices for American drivers. Though many analysts predicted that the group might pause the monthly increases it agreed on in July, or even cut output, others said the decision taken on Thursday made sense. No one yet knows whether the new Omicron variant will prove a big hit to the economy, a passing worry or something in between. A hasty halt to the production increases might also have sent a negative signal to the markets about the group’s view of the global economy. At the moment, oil market fundamentals remain strong. In recent months, strong demand for oil and the producers’ restraint on output have drained stockpiles to low levels. And analysts pointed out that future demand is probably holding up at least in the short term. “Middle East OPEC members will likely have seen good demand for their crude in January,” analysts from FGE, a consulting firm, said in a report on Thursday, as Asian economies powered ahead. Maintaining the planned increase will probably also ease friction with the Biden administration, which last month orchestrated a planned release of oil stocks from the United States Strategic Petroleum Reserve in conjunction with smaller moves by other large oil consumers. The unusual rebellion over prices, which included China, Japan, India and South Korea, all key customers for Persian Gulf oil producers, is a worrying development for countries like Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. It could ultimately threaten both their national finances, which are dependent on oil revenue, and their control of markets. The planned release of the oil reserves, coupled with the impact of the new variant, have pushed prices down more than 17 percent since the seven-year highs of about $85 a barrel reached in October — probably accomplishing much of what the White House wanted. Analysts say lower prices will not only ease tensions with Washington but also accomplish other OPEC Plus goals, including discouraging investment in shale oil drilling  in the United States. Current prices may also reduce the incentive for the Biden administration to reach a nuclear deal with Iran in ongoing indirect talks. An Iran free of sanctions could quickly put substantial volumes of oil on the market, a potential worry for Tehran’s fellow members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, like Saudi Arabia. Some analysts say that OPEC Plus may just be postponing inevitable cuts in deference to Washington, and that it will need to squeeze output if it wants to protect prices. “The longer they wait, the more they may need to do,” said Bill Farren-Price, a director at Enverus, a market research firm. Still, for a diverse group like OPEC Plus, sticking to a plan at a time of uncertainty is an easier sell than a change of course.
~~~~~
COMMENT:  The key statement to me in this article was that their decisions put a floor under the price.

Wow. Looks like this unexpected slump — caused by apparent market uncertainty in light of the new Omicron developments — has some staying power. Normally I wouldn’t change my forecast so drastically, but the ever-shrinking question timeframe is playing heavily into my thinking, as is the nearly $10/bbl price jump that would be needed to get back into bin #5.

Covid drives down the price.   The situation we arrived at in April 2020 where the price plummeted to below zero is not likely to happen again as producers will be wary of the danger - hence i am discounting <$30 and giving <$45 a low chance.  Omicron has already exerted downward pressure on prices.  We have a better handle on Omicron's ability to evade vaccines by mid December.  Until then expect demand to drop and prices with it.  If Omicron proves to not be a serious risk to public health, prices will rebound.  I am giving this a fairly high chance.  If Omicron proves to be dangerous, or still an unknown quantity, demand will remain low, prices will stay below average (c.$69 for 2021).   Even if early data shows good vaccine response to Omicron, people who consider themselves more vulnerable will remain cautious and limit travel.  The holiday period in much of the world will also limit demand.  I am therefore discounting the highest brackets.
Unlikely for there to be a drastic change in so short a time
Demand will go up\, supply won't.

If this question’s timeframe would’ve been a month or two longer, I wouldn’t feel the need to update my forecast at this point. My strong sense is that prices will continue to be driven by longer term fundamental trends (global demand keeps increasing as the world rebounds from COVID, while the major international oil companies remain hesitant to invest in new production to the extent that it would take to balance). However, oil prices have been “oscillating” around the longer term trend all year, experiencing a ~monthlong decrease in March/April and an even longer one in July/August. Current politically driven efforts to provide short term relief in oil prices might be driving the current “oscillation”. For the purposes of this question, this means that a scenario seems increasingly likely where prices dip into bin #4 before rising back to bin #5 AFTER the question timeframe has elapsed.
Tilting downwards given covid news coming out of europe
Losing $75 would cause me to pivot
Revised forecast.  Price is constant in this range but is "testing" 90.  Will need a shock to go over .. which could happen

Black swans aside, I’m having a very hard time seeing any “ > $90/bbl by year end” scenarios play out now. Production—particularly from OPEC but also increasingly US unconventional oil—will very likely keep increasing for the rest of the year at these prices. Further, if Biden turns on the spigot from the strategic reserve, that could cause real downward motion in prices (to the point where we could briefly be in bin #4 territory right when it counts). Demand also seems quite unlikely to drive prices up by growing quickly, given “mixed” global outlooks (I’m not exactly seeing headlines about booms in China, Europe, US) and there (frustratingly!) remains a continued threat of another big economic slowdown somewhere globally from a current or future holiday COVID spike, particularly in Europe.  Almost all of my probability on bin #6 therefore now represents “unknown unknowns”, and bin #4 seems increasingly unlikely but still very credible if demand turns out to be much weaker than ~status quo, or if one of the unlikely “very high supply” scenarios out there actually happened. 6-week timeframe on this question is really starting to kick in for my thinking as well. I just wish I had the clarity of vision that @Hesch apparently does! Perhaps, if I work at it, I’ll get there one day!

I'm guessing prices will average about 85 for a couple of months; with China's economy slowing down & the U.S. recovery hitting a weak patch, there should be enough time for supplier to ramp up production.

Update reflects today’s surprising and sizable price drop, consistent with the emerging storyline that WTI may actually be on a declining trend now for the near term. Also out there in the press is a suggestion that the price drop could be partially caused by an increased supply outlook caused by a report that Iran nuclear talks may resume soon, but I’m not buying at all that such protracted and uncertain negotiations would cause such an immediate drop in prices.

First update to my initial forecast, based on an experimental methodology: I've calculated a diverse "envelope" of different visually credible fits to the YTD daily WTI price data, and extrapolated the various models' predictions (and associated error models, based on residuals to YTD data) to the target date. Extrapolation from some higher-order fits seems to create predictions that are more consistent with the most recent (last few weeks/last few months) trends, while simple "straight-line" fits provide a longer-range perspective through time. Since 2021 has had its share of major news events and uncertainty, residual errors from the fits might be interpretable as indicative of the most likely range of deviations--and their relative probability--that might be induced by future news events in the next few months (assuming the events are not too extreme in impact). I'm planning to evaluate this general approach in a number of future forecasts involving time-series data, to see if an ensemble of my "gut-based fits" can systematically outperform my usual "gut-based" forecasting based on simple visual extrapolation or reference to a small number of simple data fitting calculations.

I estimated the chances of extreme outcomes (less than $60/bbl, greater than $90/bbl) loosely, based on the long-term historical WTI price history.
Outcomes between $60/bbl and $90/bbl are by far the most likely right now based on current trends (choose your favorite straight-line or curved fit). Large week-to-week fluctuations outside of longer-term trends--unpredictable supply or demand shocks caused by world events--will likely generate large deviations from the long-term trend anyway. More subtle differentiation of probabilities within the $60/bbl to $90/bbl range therefore seems very subjective to me this far in advance!

Quantitative analysis showed large price fluctuations in the past 10 years. over 4 months, there are considerable chances (10%) of reaching a -60 or a +30 price variation, which forces us to give some chances to the extreme scenarios. Reading on the current news, and expecting the market to be affected by the third/fourth covid wave, we believe there are more chances of a decline than a growth, yet not a decline in the materiality of the April 2020 drop. Probabilities were selected by using a weighted average (1/3-2/3) over the quant method and our group subjective estimate.

Updated probabilities: OPEC+ (including Russia) announced that they are not planning to ease oil production in the coming months, despite US pressure to add supplies to check an oil price rise. So I am not seeing lower prices very likely in the near future despite slowing economy in China.

It is expected that the new wave of restrictions induced by Covid variants to have a negative impact on economic life, therefore on WTI price. The deeper the fall, the greater the recovery. Even with the recent increase in Covid-Delta infections, don’t expect the price to drop as low as on April 21, 2020 ($ 11.26), so should expect the December 31, 2021 price to remain under the July 1, 2021 pick of $ 75.23.
Other pros that could give an extra boost to the WTI oil price: year end shopping spree, governments decision to push for higher vaccination rates, push for 3rd vax, low Covid mortality, additional anti-Covid cures, and no OPEC disputes. Also any major disruption in oil extraction-production-transport due to terrorist attacks could raise the price.

Price currently sitting at $68 per barrel. $16 per barrel was briefly hit during initial COVID shutdowns, but supply has adjusted and now the world is reopening. We have peaked around $75 on July 2nd so I'm really thinking that the price is somewhere in the $67 to $73 range, but there's a possibility of it creeping into the next bracket. As always, there could be some crazy event sending oil prices skyward or, more likely, diving below $60. We will have to wait and see how Delta affects businesses. I'm thinking people are trying to will the world back into being open and feel much more confident with the vaccine numbers continuing to rise. Don't necessarily believe this is an accurate worldview, but things continue to push forward.

It seems like the tail outcomes aren't being given enough weight here. The current price is $71. Finishing above $90 would be around a 26% increase. Looking at monthly data since 2000, there have been 26 times (10%) of 5 month periods where prices increased by more than 26%. In 4% of 5 month periods prices decreased by more than 37% , which would mean below $45. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/WTISPLC#0

@Jprice94 @mkarbowsky @Pablo_Vargas
This question layers in thoughts about the economy, the state of COVID, inflation and the behavior of OPEC and Russia. Right now I think the safest bet is in the middle. The 60-75 range represents fairly strong demand from strong economic activity. I don't think COVID is going to be a limiting factor on demand because even if there are mask mandates, the economy is up and running. I think the oil producers are biased toward pumping more and holding on to market share. I don't think inflation is going to push oil prices up -- the relationship tends to work the other way. What to you all think?
